quotes.quote: The best Startups don't create noise. They create a gravitational pull.
Most startups actually start down and only go up if they catch the winds of market demand.
Startups are based in faith, and the ones that succeed have no fear.
Startups live at the intersection of existential crisis and everything going perfectly great.
When you're in a startup, the first ten people will determine whether the company succeeds or not.
A startup is a temporary organization designed to search for a repeatable and scalable business model.

In the startup work environment, you get to have a relationship with your boss, the investors, and the key members of the team. Startups are like families - you see the good, the bad and the ugly, but in the end, you've got each other's back.
Most startup failures result from entrepreneurs who are better at making excuses than products.
In a startup, both the problem and solution are unknown.
In a startup no facts exist inside the building, only opinions.
A startup can focus on only one metric. So you have to decide what that is and ignore everything else.
For a startup, you need to stay small so the others don't attack, or you aim to be one of the big guys. If you don't do it right, you might lose everything.
Every startup has a chance to change the world, by bringing not just a new product, but an entirely new institution into existence.

Startups, by their nature, are entrepreneurial - testing new things, launching new products, and disrupting themselves. That's why you join a startup in the first place - to create, to stretch beyond your current capabilities, and to make an outsized impact.
Building a startup community is not a zero-sum game in which there are winners and losers: if everyone engages, they and the entire community can all be winners.
By definition, startups are not constrained by the limits of established company culture. And so they push boundaries and develop new technologies and ways of doing things.

A startup is the largest endeavor over which you can have definite mastery. You can have agency not just over your own life, but over a small and important part of the world. It begins by rejecting the unjust tyranny of Chance. You are not a lottery ticket.
Starting a startup is a process of trial and error. What guided the founders through this process was their empathy for the users. They never lost sight of making things that people would want.
Working on a startup is a balancing act: being crazy enough to believe your idea can take off but not crazy enough to miss the signs when it's clearly not going to.
Founding a successful startup is no different than forming a rock band.
A startup is literally just a series of unfortunate events where you failed, failed, failed, and failed until you succeed.
Startups often have to do dubious things.
Good startups usually take 10 years.
Doing startups is all about making mistakes.
The only way to train for a startup is by starting.
The lean startup method is not about cost, it is about speed.
In a startup, absolutely nothing happens unless you make it happen.
The best startups generally come from somebody needing to scratch an itch.
We can never have enough startups that are pursuing unique solutions to important problems.
Startups are not the best choice for work-life balance, and that's sort of just the sad reality.
